article.title: Upgrading Sync Gateway without spare nodes
article.description: If you do not have spare nodes, you can perform an in-place upgrade using only the current nodes.

introduction.paragraph: In an active Couchbase Mobile deployment, you can upgrade existing Sync Gateway nodes without using spare nodes. Before you you take a node offline to upgrade Sync Gateway, you redistribute traffic to the other Sync Gateway nodes. You repeat the upgrade procedure for each node.
The upgrade is an online upgrade. There is no downtime, and traffic between Couchbase Mobile-enabled apps and Couchbase Server through Sync Gateway is not affected.
introduction.note: Consider this approach if your deployment has three or more Sync Gateway nodes and if resource utilization on the Sync Gateway nodes is not high. If your deployment has two Sync Gateway nodes, an upgrade without using spare nodes is not recommended because a single point of failure during the upgrade (one Sync Gateway node) would result in a service outage.

body.paragraph: This section summarizes the upgrade procedure in two ways: with a high-level overview of the procedure (without the individual steps) and a flowchart. It also directs you to an example of this type of upgrade.
For an upgrade without using spare nodes, you will:

ordered-list.list-item: Prepare all nodes for the upgrade. Obtain the platform-specific binary file (an RPM package file on CentOS) for Sync Gateway and manage Sync Gateway configuration files.
Begin iteratively upgrading nodes. At the reverse proxy, redirect traffic away from one Sync Gateway node, distributing the traffic over the remaining nodes. Verify that traffic is flowing.
Upgrade the now quiet Sync Gateway node: stop the running Sync Gateway, uninstall the old version, install the new version, and then start Sync Gateway.

If there are additional nodes to upgrade, repeat the tasks of redistribution and upgrading nodes (steps 1 and 2). At the reverse proxy, redirect traffic to the upgraded Sync Gateway node. If there are more nodes to upgrade, you can redirect traffic away from the next node at the same time.
Redistribute traffic across all Sync Gateway nodes and verify that traffic is flowing.

body.paragraph: This flowchart diagrams the upgrade procedure. Explanations that correspond to the numbers follow the flowchart.
As you can see from this example, the pattern for an upgrade is:

ordered-list.list-item: Direct traffic away from a node to be upgraded and to other nodes.
Upgrade the node: stop Sync Gateway, uninstall Sync Gateway, install the new version of Sync Gateway, and start Sync Gateway.
Repeat steps 1 and 2 for all nodes that you are upgrading (the total number of nodes less the number of spare nodes).
Redistribute traffic across all nodes.

body.paragraph: For an example of the upgrade process, see "Without spare nodes."

body.note: This procedure uses sample directory names, file names, and IP addresses. Replace the values shown with values for your deployment.
body.paragraph: Following is the complete upgrade procedure for an upgrade without using spare nodes.
To prepare for the upgrade, log in as an administrator on each Sync Gateway node and perform the following tasks:

ordered-list.list-item: Obtain the platform-specific binary file (an RPM package file on CentOS) for the new version of Sync Gateway from the Downloads page. Choose Red Hat enterprise edition.
Create a directory in which to save Sync Gateway configuration files: $ mkdir ~/config-files
Change your working directory to the config-files directory: $ cd ~/config-files
Save the configuration file for the current version of Sync Gateway: $ cp /opt/Couchbase-sync-gateway/config.json ./config_A.json
Make a copy of the configuration file to use with the new version of Sync Gateway: $ cp config_A.json config_B.json

Edit the new configuration file if desired. Because the new Sync Gateway will reference the bucket and host name of the same Couchbase Server node, editing the Sync Gateway configuration file is probably not necessary.

body.note: This is the beginning of an iterative series of redistributions of traffic and node upgrades. During each iteration, you will upgrade one Sync Gateway node.
body.paragraph: To upgrade existing Sync Gateway nodes, log in as an administrator on the reverse-proxy node and perform the following tasks:

ordered-list.list-item: Reload the nginx configuration file. This redistributes the traffic: $ nginx –s reload
Verify that traffic is flowing.

body.paragraph: Traffic is now flowing through Sync Gateway nodes 42 and 43, but not through node 41. You are ready to upgrade node 41.
Log in as an administrator on the Sync Gateway node that you plan to upgrade and perform the following tasks:

ordered-list.list-item:
Stop Sync Gateway: $ ps -ef | grep sync_gateway jeff PID 26734 0 13:45 pts/0 00:00:00 ./sync_gateway config.json jeff 28848 28832 0 13:46 pts/1 00:00:00 grep sync_gateway
$ kill -9 PID
PID is the process ID of the Sync Gateway process.
Uninstall Sync Gateway: $ rpm -e couchbase-sync-gateway
Install the new version of Sync Gateway: $ rpm –i couchbase-sync-gateway-enterprise_version.rpm The string version is a version number.
Change the working directory to the directory that contains the Sync Gateway executable file: $ cd /opt/couchbase-sync-gateway/bin
Copy the Sync Gateway configuration file into the new Sync Gateway deployment: $ cp ~/config-files/config_B.json ./config.json
Start Sync Gateway: $ nohup ./sync_gateway config.json > sg.log 2>&1 &

Verify that the Sync Gateway instance has a good connection to the Couchbase Server cluster. In a web browser, enter the following address (replace {db} with the name of the Couchbase Server database): localhost:4985/{db}_session If the browser displays JSON objects with information about the session, then the connection is good. If the browser displays a JSON object that contains the name-value pair "error": "Internal Server Error", then the connection is not good.

body.paragraph: One Sync Gateway node (41) has now been upgraded, but traffic is not flowing to it.
Repeat the process of redirecting traffic (see Redirect traffic), and then upgrading a node (see Upgrade a node) until all nodes have been upgraded.
Log in as an administrator on the reverse-proxy node and perform the following tasks:

ordered-list.list-item: Reload the nginx configuration file. This redistributes the traffic: $ nginx –s reload
Verify that traffic is flowing.

body.paragraph: Now traffic is flowing through all nodes, which have all been upgraded.
